column2: I now take it for granted that your father has forbidden our union; indeed this is the only conclusion that I can draw from your letter. Ferdinand, I can bear this, even this.
column3: I now take it for granted that your father has forbidden our union; indeed this is the only conclusion that I can draw from your letter. Ferdinand, I can bear this, even this.

column2: Sustained by your affection, I will trust to time, to events, to the kindness of my friends, and to that overruling Providence, which will not desert affections so pure as ours, to bring about sooner or later some happier result.
column3: Sustained by your affection, I will trust to time, to events, to the kindness of my friends, and to that overruling Providence, which will not desert affections so pure as ours, to bring about sooner or later some happier result.

column2: Confident in your love, I can live in solitude, and devote myself to your memory, I------
column3: Confident in your love, I can live in solitude, and devote myself to your memory, I------

column2: O Ferdinand! kneel to your father, kneel to your kind mother; tell them all, tell them how I love you, how I will love them; tell them your Henrietta will have no thought but for their happiness; tell them she will be as dutiful to them as she is devoted to you.
column3: O Ferdinand! kneel to your father, kneel to your kind mother; tell them all, tell them how I love you, how I will love them; tell them your Henrietta will have no thought but for their happiness; tell them she will be as dutiful to them as she is devoted to you.

column2: Ask not for our union, ask them only to permit you to cherish our acquaintance.
column3: Ask not for our union, ask them only to permit you to cherish our acquaintance.

column2: Let them return to Armine; let them cultivate our friendship; let them know papa; let them know me; let them know me as I am, with all my faults, I trust not worldly, not selfish, not quite insignificant, not quite unprepared to act the part that awaits a member of their family, either in its splendour or its proud humility; and, if not worthy of their son (as who can be?), yet conscious, deeply conscious of the value and blessing of his affection, and prepared to prove it by the devotion of my being.
column3: Let them return to Armine; let them cultivate our friendship; let them know papa; let them know me; let them know me as I am, with all my faults, I trust not worldly, not selfish, not quite insignificant, not quite unprepared to act the part that awaits a member of their family, either in its splendour or its proud humility; and, if not worthy of their son (as who can be?), yet conscious, deeply conscious of the value and blessing of his affection, and prepared to prove it by the devotion of my being.

column2: Do this, my Ferdinand, and happiness will yet come.
column3: Do this, my Ferdinand, and happiness will yet come.

column2: But, my gentle love, on whatever course you may decide, remember your Henrietta.
column3: But, my gentle love, on whatever course you may decide, remember your Henrietta.

column2: I do not reproach you; never will I reproach you; but remember the situation in which you have placed me.
column3: I do not reproach you; never will I reproach you; but remember the situation in which you have placed me.

column2: All my happy life I have never had a secret from my father; and now I am involved in a private engagement and a clandestine correspondence.
column3: All my happy life I have never had a secret from my father; and now I am involved in a private engagement and a clandestine correspondence.

column2: Be just to him; be just to your Henrietta!
column3: Be just to him; be just to your Henrietta!

column2: Return, I beseech you on my knees; return instantly to Ducie; reveal everything.
column3: Return, I beseech you on my knees; return instantly to Ducie; reveal everything.

column2: He will be kind and gracious; he will be our best friend; in his hand and bosom we shall find solace and support.
column3: He will be kind and gracious; he will be our best friend; in his hand and bosom we shall find solace and support.

column2: God bless you, Ferdinand!
column3: God bless you, Ferdinand!

column2: All will yet go well, mine own, own love.
column3: All will yet go well, mine own, own love.

column2: I smile amid my tears when I think that we shall so soon meet.
column3: I smile amid my tears when I think that we shall so soon meet.

column2: Oh! what misery can there be in this world if we may but share it together?
column3: Oh! what misery can there be in this world if we may but share it together?

column2: Thy fond, thy faithful, thy devoted
column3: Thy fond, thy faithful, thy devoted

column2: Henrietta.
column3: Henrietta.

column2: CHAPTER III.
column3: CHAPTER three.

column2: _Containing the Arrival at Ducie of a Distinguished Guest_.
column3: underscore Containing the Arrival at Ducie of a Distinguished Guest underscore.

column2: IT WAS about three weeks after Ferdinand Armine had quitted Ducie that Mr. Temple entered the breakfast-room one morning, with an open note in his hand, and told Henrietta to prepare for visitors, as her old friend, Lady Bellair, had written to apprise him of her intention to rest the night at Ducie, on her way to the North.
column3: IT WAS about three weeks after Ferdinand Armine had quitted Ducie that mr Temple entered the breakfast room one morning, with an open note in his hand, and told Henrietta to prepare for visitors, as her old friend, Lady Bellair, had written to apprise him of her intention to rest the night at Ducie, on her way to the North.

column2: 'She brings with her also the most charming woman in the world,' added Mr. Temple, with a smile.
column3: 'She brings with her also the most charming woman in the world,' added mr Temple, with a smile.

column2: 'I have little doubt Lady Bellair deems her companion so at present,' said Miss Temple, 'whoever she may be; but, at any rate, I shall be glad to see her ladyship, who is certainly one of the most amusing women in the world.'
column3: 'I have little doubt Lady Bellair deems her companion so at present,' said Miss Temple, 'whoever she may be; but, at any rate, I shall be glad to see her ladyship, who is certainly one of the most amusing women in the world.'

column2: This announcement of the speedy arrival of Lady Bellair made some bustle in the household of Ducie Bower; for her ladyship was in every respect a memorable character, and the butler who had remembered her visits to Mr. Temple before his residence at Ducie, very much interested the curiosity of his fellow-servants by his intimations of her ladyship's eccentricities.
column3: This announcement of the speedy arrival of Lady Bellair made some bustle in the household of Ducie Bower; for her ladyship was in every respect a memorable character, and the butler who had remembered her visits to mr Temple before his residence at Ducie, very much interested the curiosity of his fellow servants by his intimations of her ladyship's eccentricities.

column2: 'You will have to take care of the parrot, Mary,' said the butler; 'and you, Susan, must look after the page.
column3: 'You will have to take care of the parrot, Mary,' said the butler; 'and you, Susan, must look after the page.

column2: We shall all be well cross-examined as to the state of the establishment; and so I advise you to be prepared.
column3: We shall all be well cross examined as to the state of the establishment; and so I advise you to be prepared.

column2: Her ladyship is a rum one, and that's the truth.'
column3: Her ladyship is a rum one, and that's the truth.'

column2: In due course of time, a handsome travelling chariot, emblazoned with a viscount's coronet, and carrying on the seat behind a portly man-servant and a lady's maid, arrived at Ducie.
column3: In due course of time, a handsome travelling chariot, emblazoned with a viscount's coronet, and carrying on the seat behind a portly man servant and a lady's maid, arrived at Ducie.

column2: They immediately descended, and assisted the assembled household of the Bower to disembark the contents of the chariot; but Mr. Temple and his daughter were too well acquainted with Lady Bellair's character to appear at this critical moment. First came forth a stately dame, of ample proportions and exceedingly magnificent attire, being dressed in the extreme of gorgeous fashion, and who, after being landed on the marble steps, was for some moments absorbed in the fluttering arrangement of her plumage; smoothing her maroon pelisse, shaking the golden riband of her emerald bonnet, and adjusting the glittering pelerine of point device, that shaded the fall of her broad but well-formed shoulders.
column3: They immediately descended, and assisted the assembled household of the Bower to disembark the contents of the chariot; but mr Temple and his daughter were too well acquainted with Lady Bellair's character to appear at this critical moment. First came forth a stately dame, of ample proportions and exceedingly magnificent attire, being dressed in the extreme of gorgeous fashion, and who, after being landed on the marble steps, was for some moments absorbed in the fluttering arrangement of her plumage; smoothing her maroon pelisse, shaking the golden riband of her emerald bonnet, and adjusting the glittering pelerine of point device, that shaded the fall of her broad but well formed shoulders.

column2: In one hand the stately dame lightly swung a bag that was worthy of holding the Great Seal itself, so rich and so elaborate were its materials and embroidery; and in the other she at length took a glass which was suspended from her neck by a chain-cable of gold, and glanced with a flashing eye, as dark as her ebon curls and as brilliant as her well-rouged cheek, at the surrounding scene.
column3: In one hand the stately dame lightly swung a bag that was worthy of holding the Great Seal itself, so rich and so elaborate were its materials and embroidery; and in the other she at length took a glass which was suspended from her neck by a chain cable of gold, and glanced with a flashing eye, as dark as her ebon curls and as brilliant as her well rouged cheek, at the surrounding scene.

column2: The green parrot, in its sparkling cage, followed next, and then came forth the prettiest, liveliest, smallest, best-dressed, and, stranger than all, oldest little lady in the world.
column3: The green parrot, in its sparkling cage, followed next, and then came forth the prettiest, liveliest, smallest, best dressed, and, stranger than all, oldest little lady in the world.

column2: Lady Bellair was of childlike stature, and quite erect, though ninety years of age; the tasteful simplicity of her costume, her little plain white silk bonnet, her grey silk dress, her apron, her grey mittens, and her Cinderella shoes, all admirably contrasted with the vast and flaunting splendour of her companion, not less than her ladyship's small yet exquisitely proportioned form, her highly-finished extremities, and her keen sarcastic grey eye.
column3: Lady Bellair was of childlike stature, and quite erect, though ninety years of age; the tasteful simplicity of her costume, her little plain white silk bonnet, her grey silk dress, her apron, her grey mittens, and her Cinderella shoes, all admirably contrasted with the vast and flaunting splendour of her companion, not less than her ladyship's small yet exquisitely proportioned form, her highly finished extremities, and her keen sarcastic grey eye.

column2: The expression of her countenance now, however, was somewhat serious.
column3: The expression of her countenance now, however, was somewhat serious.

column2: An arrival was an important moment that required all her practised circumspection; there was so much to arrange, so much to remember, and so much to observe.
column3: An arrival was an important moment that required all her practised circumspection; there was so much to arrange, so much to remember, and so much to observe.

column2: The portly serving-man had advanced, and, taking his little mistress in his arms, as he would a child, had planted her on the steps.
column3: The portly serving man had advanced, and, taking his little mistress in his arms, as he would a child, had planted her on the steps.

column2: And then her ladyship's clear, shrill, and now rather fretful voice was heard.
column3: And then her ladyship's clear, shrill, and now rather fretful voice was heard.

column2: 'Here! where's the butler?
column3: 'Here! where's the butler?

column2: I don't want you, stupid [addressing her own servant], but the butler of the house, Mister's butler; what is his name, Mr. Twoshoes' butler?
column3: I don't want you, stupid [addressing her own servant], but the butler of the house, Mister's butler; what is his name, mr Twoshoes' butler?

column2: I cannot remember names.
column3: I cannot remember names.

column2: Oh! you are there, are you?
column3: Oh! you are there, are you?

column2: I don't want you.
column3: I don't want you.

column2: How is your master?
column3: How is your master?

column2: How is your charming lady?
column3: How is your charming lady?

column2: Where is the parrot?
column3: Where is the parrot?

column2: I don't want it.
column3: I don't want it.

column2: Where's the lady?
column3: Where's the lady?

column2: Why don't you answer?
column3: Why don't you answer?

column2: Why do you stare so?
column3: Why do you stare so?

column2: Miss Temple!
column3: Miss Temple!

column2: no! not Miss Temple!
column3: no! not Miss Temple!

column2: The lady, my lady, my charming friend, Mrs. Floyd!
column3: The lady, my lady, my charming friend, mrs Floyd!

column2: To be sure so; why did not you say so before?
column3: To be sure so; why did not you say so before?

column2: But she has got two names.
column3: But she has got two names.

column2: Why don't you say both names?
column3: Why don't you say both names?

column2: My dear,' continued Lady Bellair, addressing her travelling companion, 'I don't know your name.
column3: My dear,' continued Lady Bellair, addressing her travelling companion, 'I don't know your name.

column2: Tell all these good people your name; your two names!
column3: Tell all these good people your name; your two names!

column2: I like people with two names.
column3: I like people with two names.

column2: Tell them, my dear, tell them; tell them your name, Mrs. Thingabob, or whatever it is, Mrs. Thingabob Twoshoes.'
column3: Tell them, my dear, tell them; tell them your name, mrs Thingabob, or whatever it is, mrs Thingabob Twoshoes.'

column2: Mrs. Montgomery Floyd, though rather annoyed by this appeal, still contrived to comply with the request in the most dignified manner; and all the servants bowed to Mrs. Montgomery Floyd.
column3: mrs Montgomery Floyd, though rather annoyed by this appeal, still contrived to comply with the request in the most dignified manner; and all the servants bowed to mrs Montgomery Floyd.

column2: To the great satisfaction of this stately dame, Lady Bellair, after scanning everything and everybody with the utmost scrutiny, indicated some intention of entering, when suddenly she turned round:
column3: To the great satisfaction of this stately dame, Lady Bellair, after scanning everything and everybody with the utmost scrutiny, indicated some intention of entering, when suddenly she turned round:

column2: 'Man, there's something wanting.
column3: 'Man, there's something wanting.

column2: I had three things to take charge of. The parrot and my charming friend; that is only two.
column3: I had three things to take charge of. The parrot and my charming friend; that is only two.

column2: There is a third. What is it?
column3: There is a third. What is it?

column2: You don't know!
column3: You don't know!

column2: Here, you man, who are you?
column3: Here, you man, who are you?

column2: Mr. Temple's servant.
column3: mr Temple's servant.

column2: I knew your master when he was not as high as that cage.
column3: I knew your master when he was not as high as that cage.

column2: What do you think of that?' continued her ladyship, with a triumphant smile. 'What do you laugh at, sir?
column3: What do you think of that?' continued her ladyship, with a triumphant smile. 'What do you laugh at, sir?

column2: Did you ever see a woman ninety years old before?
column3: Did you ever see a woman ninety years old before?

column2: That I would wager you have not.
column3: That I would wager you have not.

column2: What do I want?
column3: What do I want?

column2: I want something.
column3: I want something.

column2: Why do you tease me by not remembering what I want?
column3: Why do you tease me by not remembering what I want?

column2: Now, I knew a gentleman who made his fortune by once remembering what a very great man wanted.
column3: Now, I knew a gentleman who made his fortune by once remembering what a very great man wanted.

column2: But then the great man was a minister of state.
column3: But then the great man was a minister of state.

column2: I dare say if I were a minister of state, instead of an old woman ninety years of age, you would contrive somehow or other to find out what I wanted. Never mind, never mind.
column3: I dare say if I were a minister of state, instead of an old woman ninety years of age, you would contrive somehow or other to find out what I wanted. Never mind, never mind.

column2: Come, my charming friend, let me take your arm.
column3: Come, my charming friend, let me take your arm.

column2: Now I will introduce you to the prettiest, the dearest, the most innocent and charming lady in the world.
column3: Now I will introduce you to the prettiest, the dearest, the most innocent and charming lady in the world.

column2: She is my greatest favourite. She is always my favourite.
column3: She is my greatest favourite. She is always my favourite.

column2: You are my favourite, too; but you are only my favourite for the moment.
column3: You are my favourite, too; but you are only my favourite for the moment.

column2: I always have two favourites: one for the moment, and one that I never change, and that is my sweet Henrietta Temple.
column3: I always have two favourites: one for the moment, and one that I never change, and that is my sweet Henrietta Temple.

column2: You see I can remember her name, though I couldn't yours.
column3: You see I can remember her name, though I couldn't yours.

column2: But you are a good creature, a dear good soul, though you live in a bad set, my dear, a very bad set indeed; vulgar people, my dear; they may be rich, but they have no _ton_.
column3: But you are a good creature, a dear good soul, though you live in a bad set, my dear, a very bad set indeed; vulgar people, my dear; they may be rich, but they have no underscore ton underscore.

column2: This is a fine place.
column3: This is a fine place.

column2: Stop, stop,' Lady Bellair exclaimed, stamping her little foot and shaking her little arm, 'Don't drive away; I remember what it was.
column3: Stop, stop,' Lady Bellair exclaimed, stamping her little foot and shaking her little arm, 'Don't drive away; I remember what it was.

column2: Gregory! run, Gregory!
column3: Gregory! run, Gregory!

column2: It is the page!
column3: It is the page!

column2: There was no room for him behind, and I told him to lie under the seat.
column3: There was no room for him behind, and I told him to lie under the seat.

column2: Poor dear boy!
column3: Poor dear boy!

column2: He must be smothered.
column3: He must be smothered.

column2: I hope he is not dead. Oh! there he is.
column3: I hope he is not dead. Oh! there he is.

column2: Has Miss Temple got a page?
column3: Has Miss Temple got a page?

column2: Does her page wear a feather?
column3: Does her page wear a feather?

column2: My page has not got a feather, but he shall have one, because he was not smothered.
column3: My page has not got a feather, but he shall have one, because he was not smothered.

column2: Here! woman, who are you?
column3: Here! woman, who are you?

column2: The housemaid.
column3: The housemaid.

column2: I thought so.
column3: I thought so.

column2: I always know a housemaid.
column3: I always know a housemaid.

column2: You shall take care of my page.
column3: You shall take care of my page.

column2: Take him at once, and give him some milk and water; and, page, be very good, and never leave this good young woman, unless I send for you.
column3: Take him at once, and give him some milk and water; and, page, be very good, and never leave this good young woman, unless I send for you.

column2: And, woman, good young woman, perhaps you may find an old feather of Miss Temple's page.
column3: And, woman, good young woman, perhaps you may find an old feather of Miss Temple's page.

column2: Give it to this good little boy, because he was not smothered.'
